Reactions involve bond-breaking and bond-making
1 . The electrons redistribute (electron dynamics), in an attempt to realize other (meta-) stable configurations. Electron dynamics depend on nuclei/atomic configurations
2 . Nuclei dynamics, in turn, depend on the electron configurations
3 . Eventually, the coupled electronic and atomic dynamics proceed to some final state on the surface
4, 5 . Thus, a thorough understanding of the nature of reactions, e.g., catalysis and corrosion, entails an understanding of the elementary dynamical processes involved, in which mass, charge, and energy transport play important roles. Needless to say, this requires knowledge of the (local) atomic configurations. From this we could discern the corresponding electron distribution and local reactivity.
